review:
I played it on Linux after picking it up in a $1 bundle.
In short, this is a classic "Eurojunk" game from Hungary. The developer of this game now works in a CGI company or AAA studio (the lead developer worked on Crysis) and you can tell by the quality of the effects, the cinematography and the soundtrack. The main problem is that everything else is not so good: there are a lot of great ideas, but the controls and the UI seem so incomplete, as if the whole game was rushed after having done the 60% of it.
It's a shame, because I had more fun with it than, say, Stellaris or any of today's 4x.
The story isn't that interesting, but I appreciate the setting. 
I suggest you play it just out of curiosity or if you want to explore the incredible world of "Eurojunk" games.

Bei dem Spiel kann Steam die Spielzeit leider nicht vern√ºnftig messen. Es war ein Kampf, die Spielzeit auf die erforderlichen 5 Minuten f√ºr das Review zu bringen und das war schon fast lustiger, als das Spiel selber.

[b]Gameplay[/b]
In ‚ÄúHaegemonia: Legions of Iron‚Äù k√§mpfen wir um unser Sonnensystem und nutzen daf√ºr die Ressourcen der verschiedenen Planeten, um neue Kampfschiffe mit coolen Laserwaffen zu bauen. Diese steuern wir dann in kleinen Verb√§nden und jede Einheit kann auch im Rang aufsteigen. Am Anfang f√ºhlt sich die Steuerung ziemlich fummlig an, aber immerhin f√ºhrt einen das Spiel langsam in die Mechaniken ein. Allerdings muss man auch viel in irgendwelchen Logs nachlesen. Neben dem toten Multiplayer gibt es allerdings auch nur zwei Kampagnen, die wir auf Seiten der Erde oder dem Mars erleben k√∂nnen. Allerdings ist das Missionsdesign da oft nicht so toll. Kommst du vom Weg ab, ist die Mission meistens direkt gescheitert. Du hast grade am Anfang einfach √ºberhaupt keine spielerische Freiheit und diese k√ºnstliche Einengung nervt mich sehr. Warum kann ich denn Dieses und Jenes machen, wenn die Mission dann automatisch scheitert‚Ä¶?
Mittlerweile habe ich das Spiel √ºbrigens derma√üen hart gekillt, dass ich es nicht mehr starten konnte. Das lag vermutlich auch am selben Problem, warum die Spielzeit auf Steam nicht getrackt wird. Beim Beenden des Spiels wird n√§mlich das Spiel nicht als Prozess beendet und wenn man das Spiel dann nochmal startet, gibt es keine Fehlermeldung aus. Nee, dass w√§re ja zu einfach. Es st√ºrzt dann einfach nach 4 Sekunden ab. Aber auch so hat der Titel so manch technische Probleme, die man sehr umst√§ndlich beheben muss. Das darf bei alten Spielen nat√ºrlich vorkommen, aber hat mir hier den Rest gegeben.

[b]Story[/b]
Das Spiel verfolgt ein wenig die Story von [url=https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Expanse_(Fernsehserie)]The Expanse[/url]: Der Mars wurde besiedelt, hat sich unabh√§ngig gemacht und in einer Mischung aus kaltem und hei√üem Krieg k√§mpfen sie jetzt um die √§u√üeren Planeten des Systems. Ist jetzt nicht die neue Geschichte, auch 2002 schon nicht mehr. Einen gro√üen Pluspunkt h√§tte es gegeben, wenn auch weniger bekanntere Planeten und Monde im Spiel existieren w√ºrden, aber mehr als die gallischen Monde und Titan war nicht drin.

[b]Grafik/Sound[/b]
F√ºr 2002 ist die Grafik echt in Ordnung und die taktische Karte hilft ein wenig √ºber die Schw√§chen hinweg. Aber da gibt es ja ganz klar aktuellere Titel. Ganz nett ist auch, dass das Spiel komplett ins Deutsche √ºbersetzt wurde und die Kritk an den Sprechern w√ºrde ich hier weit hinten ansetzen. 
Denn es gibt furchtbare Buchstabenl√ºcken in der deutschen Fassung. So  scheinen alle m und f Dopplungen zu fehlen und das Spiel hat kein ck. Irgendwie echt schr√§g. W√§ren es Umlaute oder Sonderzeichen, h√§tte man das Ganze ja vielleicht noch nachvollziehen k√∂nnen. So zerst√∂rt das einfach furchtbar den Lesefluss und aus jedem ‚ÄúTr√ºmmer‚Äù wird ein ‚ÄúTr√ºer‚Äù.

[b]Fazit[/b]

review: Haegemonia may not be a big hit but it is a great RTS. Homeworld may conquer the space-based RTS genre but Haegemonia tries to expand on what Homeworld did. From the expanded research to managing planets. All the things in the game have counters and the technology will either help you win or be your demise. It's up to the choices you make to determine who will conquer the systems. And for a game made years and years ago the graphics still hold up to this day. The music is another great spot as it gets more intense with the scale of the battles. With epic music, large explosions, wreckage floating all around, and laser fire, this is a must if you love space RTS games.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972325525', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 331, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 331, 'last_played': 1408714346}
review:
Ah Haegemonia... I have a very well used disc for this in my desk and just had to buy it when I saw it on steam.

Short version: It's easily worth double the current ¬£4 price. There is a good story, music and generally a very enjoyable game here with at least 10+ hours of gameplay. You play a commander either for Earth or Mars, who has to bring a system wide civil war to a close, then the majority of the game is about advancing humanity into deep space. The exploration and research feels rich and it has some good atmosphere. It's dated, but worthwhile.

Long Version!

Pros:
- Clean, effective user interface.
- Great music that adds mystery, atmosphere and the battle music is great.
- An excellent research system where what you spend points on carries over between levels and throughout the entire game. It's really a joy to unlock things, and levels where you get a lot to spend feel awesome.
- The system for building up colonies is very intuitive, and another area where the well designed UI comes through for you.
- The story is good. There are challenges and twists as you try to secure humanity's place among the stars.
- It's somehow still rather pretty.

Cons:
- By today's standards, the graphics are a little simple. But you can look past that because they hold up well.
- The character animations when they talk to you are a bit too mannequin like.
- The unit types are a little too simplistic. Generally you'll want to build the largest 1-2 ship classes you can and ignore the earlier ones later on. Doesn't have a rock/paper/scissors mechanic to keep things viable like modern games. The weapon techs and research do tend to make up for this a bit however.

Go buy it.

Do eet.

Nao.

Before I write my review here's a link to the  "Sound error" fix : 
[b]mediafire   com/file/16787mmlm1l4u92/Hgm.exe[/b]  (Fill in the blanks)
Go offline on Steam then replace the original Hgm.exe in the game folder,then right-click it > troubleshoot compatibility > Windows XP (Service Pack 3). Don't go online until you've tested it.
Edit : This worked for me,but for one of my friends it didn't. It caused "Missing CD" error. I don't know any other way to fix it.

I have 13mins on the game here,but I've played many hours on the original CD, that is now scratched up and not functional. My review disregards the "sound error".

[h1]Review:[/h1]
I'll start off by saying the game is very old now and that you shouldn't expect anything spectacular from it.
There are:
[list][*] 3 playable races - Humans,Darzok,Kariak ; each has their own starting researched techs in any other game mode outside of the campaign. The unit types transfer between all races with a few exceptions,meaning all races have Fighters,Corvettes,Cruisers,Battleships,Military bases,Mining bases,Planetary products etc ...
[*] The campaign is long enough in combination with the other game types to justify the game's price.
[*] The difference between the Earth and Mars campaigns is only in the first missions. You basically choose which side of the conflict to start from and when the conflict ends you continue playing through the rest of the missions which are the same for either side.
[*] There are about 25 types of ships to choose from (not counting the variants of said types per race)
[*] There are 8 research trees which allow you to upgrade your ships' armament and equipment, planetary facilities and defences, spy missions etc. 4 of these research trees are weapon upgrades (1 tree for each weapon type - Proton / Missile / Ion / Quantum
[*] There are 9 maps for multiplayer - 7 scenario and 2 FFA / TDM. Since I haven't played this game's MP (due to non-existent player presense) I can't tell you how it runs and whether it's peer-to-peer or dedicated server. If you can't get it to run through Steam you and your friends could try making a game through something like Gameranger.
[*] In the multiplayer you can skirmish against AI if you can't find people to play with and you've gone through the campaign.
[/list]
[h1]Pros and cons: [/h1]
PROS :
[list][*]The game has aged very well. For a game released in 2002 the game has great graphics and possibly the prettiest explosions in a space game that can give 2010 games a run for their money.
[*]Some of the best ambient and battle soundtracks for a space game to date, in my opinion. The sound effects are also pretty good.
[*]Decent gameplay. Not as advanced unit and strategy-wise as one would expect after having played games like Homeworld. In pretty much any game mode you have to beat your opponents by Conquering them / Beating them by score. It doesn't wear off right away.
[*]Somewhat lenghty campaign. I'm not sure how long it would take one to beat it,because it depends on how much you've figured out and what difficulty you play on. The missions you're given at the start are linear,but mid-to-end game they become more open in the sense that you're free to apply your own strategies to achieve the goals.[/list]

CONS:[list]
[*]Non-existent tutorial. Your superiors in the campaign reffer you to the "USSF military database"which you know nothing about.Basically you gotta hit F1 and read everything there is. I'm including an archive with screenshots that have explanations on them for stuff the game doesn't explain.The rest you can figure out ingame when you press F1.
[*]The controls are clumsy and there isn't much you can order your units to do. Go-to,Attack,Defend,Mine and Spy on.
[*]After you beat the campaign there isn't anything else to do except spar against AI through the multiplayer mode or play with a friend.
[*]Somewhat cringy dialog sequences during the campaign between characters.
[*]Somewhat lacking unit variety. It's like chess - enough unit pieces to do the job, but not enough to greatly customize your playstile.
[*]Few multiplayer maps - as listed before 9 maps,two of which are FFA/TDM, the rest are scripted or allow a specific number of players/AI.
[/list]

Link to help images :
[b]http  mediafire  com/file/3wyr79o1r03tubu/Hegemonia+help.rar[/b]

That's pretty much it. If I've missed something,I'll come back to add it to the review.

Pro tips:
- Earth campaign : If you want Major Sanders,send a fighter squad to the malfunctioning military base in the asteroid belt in the 4th mission (I think) . He'll escape and be available to place in one of your military units.
- Any campaign : If you want the Residential base woman leader (forgot her name) to join you you must research the "population transportation ship" , produce it and send it to the system the Residential base is located as soon as possible. Someone releases poison gas in the station's ventilation system and you have to get the people out along with the leader by sending the population transportation ship next to the station.The leader is a governor you can place on one of your colonies.
- Don't send battleships anywhere without backup.They're slow and vulnerable when outnumbered and outgunned.
- In the campaigns do the Proton + Missile combo. Proton weapons can pass through shields and missiles have the highest damage per shot out of all weapons. Don't use missile units against fighters,they can easily evade them.
- If you want to spar against AI make a multiplayer game then save it and load. This will get rid of the delay between clicks and click registering ingame.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077248700', 'num_games_owned': 117, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1329, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 35, 'last_played': 1577389657}
review:
I love this game. I have loved it ever since it came out in 2002. Yes it's an older game. Yes it has bugs. But these can be worked around with a simple amount of research (like the sound error that some people get). And no it does not have widescreen support. You'll have to enjoy the game with either the black borders or a stretched image, depending on your computer's settings. Is it inconvenient? Yes. Is it game breaking? not in the slightest.

For a 2002 game, the game play is great, and the graphics are great (for a game of its era) and the explosions are great even for modern day games.

It's easy to get frustrated when you fail a mission, many people haven't quite gotten an understanding for the game yet and blame their mission failure on bugs. I've beaten the GOG version several times and I will surely play through the steam version just as many times. The replayability of this game is endless to me.

This is not a short game to play through, many missions will take hours to complete. You start out in the Earth-Mars war, you even get to choose who's side you want to fight for. These missions are introductory missions, teaching you how to play the game, planetary management, and research, and the levels get progressively harder as you go. In some missions, money management is absolutely CRUCIAL.

Battles can be quite intense at times and definitely fun to watch.

If you enjoy Space RTS games, this is definitely the best. Yes it's old, but its fun, very fun and a must have. Just make sure if you get errors, you look for the fix before rageposting about how "bad" of a game it is.

Oh and, in the first missions, make sure to press the F1 key (it will inform you of this) as all the information for controls you need will be listed there

Don't buy this in it's current state. Sound errors and no widescreen support.
I thought this deserves a new thread. The game's sound issues haven't been fixed and I get this problem continously on Win 7 x64 (about 4 or 5 missions in, when you first get access to wormholes). Play for a few minutes and bam, crash to the desktop.

There's no widescreen support, so enjoy playing at 1024x768 or 1280x960. 

I'd also like to add that I bought this game when it came out on disc back in 2002 or whenever it came out. It's a fantastic game and I love it to this day. I just wish there was a Haegemonia 2 onwards. This steam version just isn't worth your money until these 2 issues are fixed (the sound problem especially). I can play the game at 1280 with the nvidia settings (aa etc) set to max, so the lack of widescreen isn't a huge problem for me but the sound issue is.
